5d5b78699e57104f2fa03bbdf7b9197b (16:12): by annevk on Thu Feb 05 13:51:18

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:13): 5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1: The actual parsing of entities we can't really change (because of need for compat. with existing content), what we can change is what is conforming, and making & legal on its own gets fairly complex.
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:13): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, the format of entities is that above today
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (16:14): e.g. &copy= does turn into ¬©=
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:14): 5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1: It isn't. Things like &copy do parse like that, and need to for compatibility, even though they are non-conforming.
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:15): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, not every non-conforming change should be supported
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:15): 5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1: Browser vendors will not make changes to parsing that breaks existing content.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:16): (And that is absolutely non-negotiable: if the spec changes to something incompatible, we'll just break the spec)
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:16): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, does that mean <b> foo <i> bar </i> baz </b> is part of HTML5
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:16): I mean b i b i
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:16): 5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1: It has a defined parse tree. It is non-conforming.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:16): 5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1: Any character stream has a defined parse tree.
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:17): So is that valid HTML5?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:17): 5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1: No, it is non-conforming.
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:17): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, but &copy= is?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:17): 5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1: No, that is non-conforming too.
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:18): So HTML5 defines the exact behavior of non-conforming code.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:18): Yes.
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:18): And & as a literal is supported, but non-conforming.
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:18): For example: M & M
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:19): 5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1: That is legal because a whitespace character follows it
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:20): Thanks for the info, guys
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:21): 5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1: The only place you're allowed a & followed by anything within script and style
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:25): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, sure
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:25): those are defined as literal blocks terminated by strictly </script> and </style> I suppose
5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:25): this is their de-facto behavior.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:25): Yeah
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (16:25): (case insensitively)

5b1b00790db5a105e7d3f795b45b10a1 (16:28): entities are supported.. but nothing else :)
